newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - May 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - May 23.

text.p: The following stories were reported in Friday's electronic version of The Wall Street Journal:
* A move to revamp banking laws is gaining momentum even though federal regulators warn against allowing banks to merge with nonfinancial companies.
* General Motors Corp's Chevrolet Malibu is becoming a problem since one of the two plants that build it is involved in a strike.
* U.S. West Communications Group is close to a deal to sell its Minneapolis-St. Paul cable systems to Charter Communications for $600 million.
* Fidelity's Magellan fund pulled in $245.4 million in fees in the past fiscal year, representing a 33 percent drop.
* The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to issue a plan to change the way it regulates alternative stock-trading systems.
* CBS President Peter Lund is expected to resign amid a corporate shakeup.
* The New York Times named Bill Keller managing editor, putting him in line to possibly become the top editor later on.
* The European Commission is concerned with Boeing's sole-supplier agreements with U.S. airlines, and is asking that they be scrapped to clear the company's planned merger with McDonnell Douglas.
* Apple Computer has set free its Newton division, creating a separate company into an independent but wholly owned unit.
* Daimler-Benz AG is threatening to withdraw from a $1 billion minivan joint venture in China over disagreements with the government.
* Triarc abandoned plans to spin off its beverage and fast-food business, and instead will combine the lines with Snapple Beverage, which was recently acquired from Quaker Oats Co.

* Heard on the Street: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp, the world's largest phone company, has also long been saddled with one of the Earth's dumpiest stocks. But it is finally turning some heads: NTT shares are up 25 percent since April 7 amid growing optimism about its prospects in a deregulated Japanese telecoms market.

* Credit Markets: Bond prices ended lower, but recovered from the day's lows on news that Federal Reserve officials switched to a neutral monetary policy stance after voting to raise interest rates in March.
